tasks.description: As a researcher, actively develop and refine user flow diagrams within Figma for a new feature or existing product iteration. This variation focuses on exploring alternative pathways and identifying potential pain points for specific sections of a product, building upon initial high-level brainstorming. The goal is to map user interactions from a research-driven perspective, optimizing for usability and logical progression before detailed design.

example.scenario: Your team has identified a need to improve the user onboarding experience for a new mobile banking app feature: 'Budgeting Tools.' Initial high-level brainstorming has generated some core ideas. Now, as the lead UX Researcher, you need to dive deeper into specific user flows for setting up a budget and linking accounts. The goal is to explore at least three distinct flow variations within Figma, considering different user types and potential friction points identified in preliminary user interviews. You're specifically tasked with mapping the journey from a user's first interaction with the budgeting feature to successfully creating their first budget category, and then linking an external bank account.
example.userPrompt: Using Figma, create detailed user flow diagrams for the 'Budgeting Tools' feature in our new mobile banking app. Focus on two main sub-flows: 'Setting Up a New Budget Category' and 'Linking an External Bank Account.' For each, explore at least three distinct interaction pathways, annotate potential user decision points, and highlight areas where users might encounter friction based on our preliminary research insights. Document your rationale for each flow variation and prepare to present the most promising options to the design team.

tasks.task: Brainstorm and refine complex user flows
tasks.description: As a Researcher, leverage Figma's collaborative features to brainstorm and meticulously refine alternative, complex user flows for a critical product area. Focus on exploring edge cases, error states, and diverse user pathways, building upon initial concepts to achieve a robust and comprehensive understanding of user interaction. This is the third variation, emphasizing deep exploration and refinement.

example.scenario: A new feature in a financial management app involves complex user permissions and multiple approval stages. You need to ensure the user experience is seamless and intuitive, even for non-standard scenarios.
example.userPrompt: Using Figma, design and document three distinct, detailed user flows for the 'Complex Transaction Approval' feature. For each flow, include considerations for error handling, user notifications, and different user roles (e.g., initiator, approver, administrator). Focus on edge cases and provide annotations explaining your design decisions.

tasks.description: As a researcher, analyze an existing Figma design file to identify potential accessibility barriers and propose actionable improvements. This involves reviewing color contrast, font sizes, interactive element sizing, keyboard navigation considerations, and screen reader compatibility. The goal is to ensure the design is usable by individuals with diverse needs.

example.scenario: A UI/UX team has completed an initial design for a new web application dashboard in Figma and needs a thorough accessibility review before moving to development. The researcher is tasked with providing a detailed report on areas needing improvement.
example.userPrompt: Analyze the provided Figma design file for our new dashboard and suggest specific accessibility improvements across all key screens. Focus on WCAG 2.1 AA guidelines, covering areas like color contrast, typography, interactive component sizing, and potential keyboard navigation issues. Please provide concrete recommendations for each identified issue.

tasks.task: Suggest accessibility improvements in a Figma design as a Researcher.
tasks.description: As a researcher, analyze existing Figma designs or prototypes for potential accessibility barriers and suggest concrete improvements based on WCAG guidelines and inclusive design principles. This involves reviewing color contrast, typography, interactive element sizing, focus order, and alternative text considerations.

example.scenario: A product team has completed the first iteration of a new dashboard design in Figma and needs a comprehensive accessibility review before moving to development. As a researcher, you're tasked with identifying areas for improvement.
example.userPrompt: Review the provided Figma dashboard design. Identify at least 5 critical accessibility issues related to color contrast, text readability, or interactive element usability. For each issue, propose a specific, actionable improvement and reference relevant WCAG principles (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA).

tasks.task: Conduct a detailed accessibility audit of a Figma prototype and suggest specific improvements.
tasks.description: As a researcher, you are tasked with performing a comprehensive accessibility review of a given Figma prototype or design system. Your objective is to identify specific areas of non-compliance with WCAG 2.1 AA standards and propose concrete, actionable design changes directly within Figma. For each suggested improvement, explain its rationale, the specific accessibility principle it addresses, and the positive impact it will have on users with disabilities.

example.scenario: A development team is preparing to implement a new e-commerce product page designed in Figma. They require a detailed accessibility review to ensure it meets WCAG 2.1 AA standards before coding begins, specifically focusing on interactions, visual hierarchy, and information architecture.
example.userPrompt: You are a researcher conducting a detailed accessibility audit of an e-commerce product page prototype in Figma. Identify all areas that do not meet WCAG 2.1 AA guidelines. For each identified issue, suggest a specific, actionable design change that can be implemented in Figma, explain the accessibility benefit for users with disabilities, and categorize the issue by WCAG principle (Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, Robust).

tasks.task: Suggest accessibility improvements for a Figma design
tasks.description: As a researcher, analyze existing Figma prototypes or UI designs to identify accessibility barriers based on WCAG guidelines and inclusive design principles. Document findings and propose concrete, actionable improvements, focusing on aspects like color contrast, typography, keyboard navigation, and screen reader compatibility.

example.scenario: A UX research team has completed the initial wireframes and low-fidelity prototypes for a new e-commerce checkout flow in Figma. The lead researcher needs to conduct an accessibility audit to ensure the design is usable by people with various disabilities before moving to high-fidelity design. They are looking for specific issues related to visual impairments, motor disabilities, and cognitive load across the entire flow.
example.userPrompt: You are a UX accessibility expert. Review the attached Figma file (link provided) of our e-commerce checkout flow prototype. Identify any potential WCAG 2.1 AA violations or general accessibility barriers. For each issue, describe the problem, its impact on users, and suggest a specific, actionable improvement within Figma. Focus on color contrast, font legibility, interactive element sizing, logical tab order, and clear error states. Provide a prioritized list of findings.

tasks.description: As a researcher, your task is to leverage Figma's component variants feature to create a flexible and testable design system. This involves defining properties and values for a core UI component, such as a button or card, to explore different states, sizes, or themes. The goal is to prepare versatile design assets that can be easily manipulated for user testing scenarios or to represent different iterations in a research study without duplicating entire components.

example.scenario: A researcher is preparing a set of interactive prototypes for a user study. They need to test how users interact with different states and styles of a 'Call to Action' button.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, I need to create a 'Call to Action Button' component in Figma with several variants. I want to define properties for 'State' (Default, Hover, Pressed, Disabled) and 'Style' (Primary, Secondary, Tertiary). How do I set up a component set with these properties and their respective variants so I can easily switch between them in my prototypes for user testing?

tasks.description: As a researcher, analyze existing design patterns and user feedback to define and create a comprehensive set of component variants within Figma. This involves defining different states, sizes, and interactive properties for a specific component to ensure it meets various use cases and contributes to a robust design system. Focus on documenting the rationale behind each variant.

example.scenario: A UX researcher is tasked with standardizing a new 'Notification Banner' component. They need to create variants for different types (success, warning, error, info), states (default, dismissed), and sizes (compact, standard) within Figma, ensuring each variant is clearly labeled and documented for the design system library.
example.userPrompt: Show me how to create and organize component variants in Figma for a 'Notification Banner', including different types, states, and sizes, and how to add descriptions for each variant.

tasks.description: A researcher needs to synthesize complex findings and data into clear, concise, and engaging textual content for a PowerPoint presentation. This involves outlining key messages, structuring information logically across slides, drafting text for titles, bullet points, and potentially speaker notes, often based on extensive research papers, reports, or raw data.

example.scenario: Dr. Anya Sharma is preparing to present her latest findings on the efficacy of a new drug compound at an upcoming medical conference. She has a detailed research paper and raw clinical trial data, but needs to distill this information into impactful, audience-friendly content for her 15-slide PowerPoint presentation.
example.userPrompt: I need to create the slide content for a 20-minute scientific presentation on 'Novel Therapeutics for Autoimmune Diseases'. I have a full research paper and clinical trial data. Please help me outline the structure for 10-12 slides, draft concise bullet points for key findings and methodology, and suggest textual content for the introduction and conclusion slides, ensuring it's clear for both specialists and general practitioners.

tasks.task: Create detailed slide content for a PowerPoint presentation
tasks.description: As a researcher, the task involves generating comprehensive and structured content (text, bullet points, and brief descriptions) for a multi-slide PowerPoint presentation on a given topic. This variation focuses on creating the core textual information for the slides, not the visual design.

example.scenario: A researcher needs to prepare the textual content for a 15-minute PowerPoint presentation for an academic conference. The presentation is on 'The Efficacy of Mindfulness Interventions on Reducing Burnout in Healthcare Professionals'. They need engaging and informative content for each section of the presentation.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, generate detailed slide content for a 15-minute PowerPoint presentation titled 'The Efficacy of Mindfulness Interventions on Reducing Burnout in Healthcare Professionals'. The presentation should be structured into: Introduction, Literature Review (brief), Methodology, Key Findings, Discussion/Implications, and Conclusion. For each section, provide specific bullet points and concise descriptions suitable for a professional audience of medical researchers and practitioners.

tasks.description: As a researcher, meticulously craft and integrate detailed speaker notes directly within a PowerPoint presentation to provide a script or talking points for each slide, ensuring clarity and comprehensive coverage of the research findings for an audience.

example.scenario: A research scientist has developed a complex PowerPoint presentation detailing their latest findings on quantum computing applications. They need to prepare for an upcoming scientific conference by adding thorough speaker notes to each slide, ensuring they can explain intricate details and answer potential questions effectively during their talk.
example.userPrompt: Generate comprehensive speaker notes for a 20-slide PowerPoint presentation titled 'Novel Applications of Quantum Entanglement in Secure Communication'. For each slide, include an introduction, key points to emphasize, data interpretation, and potential audience questions to address. Ensure the language is precise and suitable for an expert scientific audience, and allocate approximately 2-3 minutes of speaking time per slide.

tasks.task: Write detailed speaker notes for a research presentation
tasks.description: As a researcher preparing for a presentation, write comprehensive and engaging speaker notes for each slide in a PowerPoint presentation. The notes should elaborate on key points, provide additional context, cite sources where necessary, guide the presenter on delivery, suggest pauses, and ensure a smooth, informative, and well-timed talk for an academic or professional audience.

example.scenario: A research scientist has finalized the visual content of their 12-slide PowerPoint presentation for an upcoming academic conference. They now need to create comprehensive speaker notes for each slide to ensure they deliver a clear, concise, and impactful presentation that covers all key points and addresses potential questions, while also managing their time effectively.
example.userPrompt: I have completed my PowerPoint presentation on 'Advances in Gene Editing Technologies.' I need to write detailed speaker notes for each of the 12 slides. For slide 4, 'CRISPR-Cas9 Mechanism,' I want to explain the process step-by-step in simple terms, include a historical context, and note a key 'aha!' moment for the audience. For slide 8, 'Ethical Considerations,' I need to outline common ethical dilemmas and my stance, ensuring I maintain a neutral, research-focused tone. Please help me generate these notes, ensuring they flow logically, provide sufficient detail beyond what's on the slide, and are suitable for a 15-minute presentation.

tasks.task: Write Speaker Notes for a PowerPoint Presentation
tasks.description: As a researcher, prepare comprehensive and clear speaker notes for an existing PowerPoint presentation. These notes should complement the visual content of each slide, provide additional detailed information, explain complex concepts or data, and guide the presenter effectively through the material. The focus is on ensuring accuracy, conciseness, and clarity of scientific or technical information for the intended audience.

example.scenario: A researcher has developed a PowerPoint presentation outlining their latest findings on 'Sustainable Urban Development Strategies'. They now need to add detailed speaker notes to each slide to ensure the presenter (either themselves or a colleague) can deliver the information accurately, comprehensively, and confidently during an upcoming academic seminar, without relying solely on the visual cues of the slides.
example.userPrompt:
You are a researcher who has just finalized a 20-slide PowerPoint presentation on 'Optimizing Waste-to-Energy Systems for Medium-Sized Cities'. Your task is to write detailed speaker notes for each slide. For each slide, your notes should:
1.  Elaborate on the key points presented visually.
2.  Provide additional data or background information not explicitly on the slide.
3.  Explain any complex diagrams, graphs, or methodologies.
4.  Suggest transitions between slides.
5.  Include anticipated questions and brief answers where appropriate.
The target audience is city planners and environmental engineers. Start with the introduction slide and ensure a consistent, professional tone throughout.

tasks.description: A researcher needs to generate detailed, data-driven content for a PowerPoint presentation, transforming complex research findings into clear and concise bullet points suitable for an academic or professional audience.

example.scenario: A research scientist has concluded a study on the efficacy of a new drug compound and needs to present their findings at a medical conference. They need compelling, accurate content for their slides without focusing on design elements.
example.userPrompt: Generate detailed content for a 12-slide PowerPoint presentation titled 'Novel Compound X: Efficacy and Safety Profile in Pre-clinical Trials'. Include content for an executive summary, methodology, key results on efficacy (with specific data points/trends), safety observations, discussion of implications, and future research directions. Each slide should have a concise title and 3-5 bullet points of information. Focus on scientific rigor and clarity.

tasks.description: Generate detailed and concise textual content, including bullet points, key findings, and summaries, for specific slides within a PowerPoint presentation based on research data and findings. This task focuses on drafting the core information that will be presented, not the visual design.

example.scenario: A researcher needs to prepare a presentation summarizing the results of their latest study on climate change's impact on polar ecosystems for an upcoming academic conference.
example.userPrompt: Generate concise bullet points for three PowerPoint slides based on my research. The first slide should outline the 'Key Findings' of how rising temperatures affect Arctic wildlife migration patterns. The second should detail 'Methodology', including satellite tracking and field observations. The third should present 'Conclusion & Future Work', highlighting the urgency and next research steps. Ensure data points are summarized and the language is academic yet accessible.

tasks.task: Summarize Data for Charts in PowerPoint
tasks.description: Extract critical insights and trends from raw data to create concise summaries, which will then be visually represented through charts in a PowerPoint presentation for stakeholders or internal teams.

example.scenario: A research team has completed a large-scale market study, generating hundreds of data points on consumer behavior. The lead researcher needs to present the core findings and recommendations to the executive board.
example.userPrompt: I need to condense the key statistical findings from our market research into 6-8 impactful charts for a PowerPoint presentation. Each chart must have a clear, concise summary statement highlighting the main takeaway for the executive board, focusing on actionable insights.

tasks.description: Draft comprehensive speaker notes for a research presentation in PowerPoint. These notes should elaborate on slide content, provide additional context, cue the presenter on key talking points, and ensure a smooth delivery during a conference or seminar.

example.scenario: A research scientist has completed their PowerPoint slides for an upcoming academic conference. They now need to create detailed speaker notes to ensure they can deliver a clear, concise, and informative presentation that covers all critical aspects of their research findings within the allotted time.
example.userPrompt: Generate speaker notes for a 20-minute PowerPoint presentation on 'Novel Approaches to Quantum Machine Learning'. For each slide, include an introduction, explanation of key figures or data, potential discussion points, and a concluding remark. Assume the presentation has 12 slides and is highly technical.

tasks.description: As a researcher, prepare detailed and comprehensive speaker notes for an existing PowerPoint presentation. These notes should elaborate on complex methodologies, interpret data findings, provide context, anticipate audience questions, and ensure a smooth, informative delivery of research without cluttering the slides.

example.scenario: Dr. Elena Petrova, a research scientist, has completed the visual slides for her upcoming presentation on 'Advances in Gene Editing Technologies' for an academic symposium. Her slides are visually rich with diagrams and concise data summaries, but lack the detailed explanations required for a comprehensive oral delivery. She needs to meticulously write speaker notes for each slide to ensure she covers all the nuanced scientific details, contextualizes complex processes, clarifies experimental results, and maintains a logical flow during her presentation, allowing her to engage with the audience while delivering precise information.
example.userPrompt: As a research scientist, I need to write detailed speaker notes for my PowerPoint presentation on gene editing. My slides are ready, but they only show high-level data and diagrams. Please help me draft comprehensive notes for each slide that include in-depth explanations of the methodologies, interpretations of experimental results, background context, and cues for smooth transitions, ensuring I deliver a clear and scientifically accurate presentation.

tasks.description: Design and implement an automated sequence of emails and actions within HubSpot to nurture new leads, guiding them through the sales funnel from initial interest to qualification. This involves defining trigger events, segmentation criteria, content stages, and conversion goals.

example.scenario: A researcher at a B2B SaaS company needs to set up an automated lead nurturing workflow in HubSpot to engage leads who have recently downloaded a product-specific case study. The workflow should educate these leads about the product's benefits, address common pain points, and encourage them to book a demo.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, I need to create a lead nurturing workflow in HubSpot for new leads who downloaded our 'Advanced Analytics' case study. The workflow should consist of 3-5 emails, sent over two weeks, that provide more in-depth content, highlight key features, and include a clear call-to-action for booking a demo. How would I structure this in HubSpot, including segmenting based on email engagement?

tasks.task: Design and Implement a Data-Driven Lead Nurturing Workflow in HubSpot
tasks.description: As a researcher, design and implement a sophisticated, multi-stage lead nurturing workflow within HubSpot. This involves conducting an initial analysis of lead sources and buyer personas, defining specific lead qualification criteria, mapping relevant content assets (emails, blog posts, webinars, case studies, etc.) to different stages of the buyer's journey, and configuring automated sequences with branching logic based on lead behavior and engagement. The objective is to optimize lead progression, improve conversion rates, and ensure seamless hand-off to sales with comprehensive tracking and reporting.

example.scenario: A marketing research team is launching a new product line and needs to develop a highly effective lead nurturing strategy. The researcher is responsible for designing the complete lifecycle of leads who enter the funnel from various sources (e.g., content downloads, event registrations) and guiding them towards becoming sales-qualified opportunities. They need to leverage HubSpot's full automation capabilities to achieve this, focusing on data-driven decision-making and continuous optimization.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, I need to create a comprehensive lead nurturing workflow in HubSpot for our new 'InnovatePro' SaaS solution. The workflow should segment leads based on initial engagement (e.g., whitepaper download vs. demo request), nurture them with tailored content over several weeks, and include clear qualification criteria and sales hand-off points. I need to define the content sequence for each path, set up automation rules for email delivery and task creation, and ensure robust tracking is in place to measure effectiveness. How should I structure this workflow, considering advanced branching logic and lead scoring integration?

tasks.description: As a researcher, draft a comprehensive blog post on a specific industry topic, leveraging HubSpot's content creation tools for drafting, SEO optimization, and scheduling. This variation focuses on integrating recent research findings and data-driven insights into the post to establish thought leadership.

example.scenario: The content marketing team needs a new blog post that highlights the company's expertise in sustainable energy. As a researcher, you've recently compiled a report on 'The Global Shift Towards Renewable Energy Sources.' You are tasked with transforming your key findings and statistics into an engaging blog post using HubSpot's content editor, ensuring it's SEO-optimized and ready for the editorial review process.
example.userPrompt: Draft a 1200-word blog post titled 'The Future is Green: Navigating the Global Shift to Renewable Energy' using HubSpot. Incorporate at least five key statistics and three actionable insights from your latest research report. Target the primary keyword 'renewable energy trends' and suggest secondary keywords. Ensure the post is well-structured, engaging, and optimized for SEO within HubSpot before submitting it for review.

tasks.task: Write and Optimize a Blog Post for Lead Generation in HubSpot
tasks.description: As a researcher, draft, optimize, and prepare a blog post for publication within HubSpot, focusing on advanced SEO, content structure for lead generation, and integration of conversion assets. This involves utilizing HubSpot's content editor, SEO tools, and CTA/form builders to create a high-performing blog post that aligns with broader marketing campaigns and tracks key performance indicators.

example.scenario: A marketing team researcher is tasked with creating a critical blog post for an upcoming product feature launch. This post must be highly optimized for search engines, engaging for the target audience, and specifically designed to drive lead capture directly within HubSpot. The researcher needs to use HubSpot's full suite of content tools to not only draft the content but also perform advanced SEO analysis, embed specific calls-to-action (CTAs) and forms, and ensure all tracking mechanisms are correctly configured to measure post-publication performance and attribute leads to the associated marketing campaign.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, draft a detailed blog post in HubSpot about our new 'Predictive Analytics' feature. Optimize it for SEO using keywords like 'predictive marketing analytics' and 'customer behavior forecasting.' Ensure the post includes a prominent CTA to download our 'Predictive Analytics Guide' and is linked to the 'Q3 Innovation Campaign' for lead tracking and reporting.

tasks.description: Creating targeted contact segments within HubSpot based on various criteria (e.g., demographics, behavior, lead source, engagement) to facilitate personalized communication, analyze campaign performance, or prepare for specific research initiatives.

example.scenario: A market researcher needs to analyze the engagement rates of contacts who have interacted with specific product-related content versus those who haven't, to identify potential high-value leads and inform content strategy.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, I need to create an active list in HubSpot that segments contacts who have viewed at least three pages related to 'Product X' within the last 30 days and have also opened at least one email from our 'Product X updates' campaign. How do I set this up to monitor their ongoing engagement?

tasks.task: Segment contact lists for in-depth analysis
tasks.description: As a researcher, meticulously segment contact lists within HubSpot based on specific behavioral, demographic, and lifecycle properties to create highly targeted audiences for advanced data analysis and trend identification. This involves combining multiple filter criteria, excluding certain groups, and saving these segments for ongoing research.

example.scenario: A researcher needs to analyze the engagement patterns of a specific customer segment who have recently interacted with premium content and are nearing the 'Opportunity' lifecycle stage, to understand conversion drivers and inform sales strategies.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, I need to create a HubSpot contact segment for analysis. I want to include all contacts who have downloaded our 'Advanced Analytics Report' in the last 3 months AND have visited at least 5 product pages AND are currently in the 'Marketing Qualified Lead' lifecycle stage, but exclude any contacts associated with our 'Partner Program'. How do I construct this complex segment for my research?

tasks.description: As a researcher, segmenting contact lists in HubSpot involves creating targeted groups of contacts based on specific criteria (e.g., demographics, behavior, engagement, source). This enables more focused analysis, personalized communication, and efficient campaign management. The process includes defining segmentation rules, applying filters, and saving dynamic lists for ongoing use in research, reporting, or marketing initiatives.

example.scenario: A market researcher needs to analyze the engagement rates of contacts from a specific industry who have attended at least one webinar and downloaded a particular whitepaper within the last six months. They want to create a dynamic list in HubSpot to track these contacts and prepare a report on their behavior.
example.userPrompt: Create a dynamic contact list in HubSpot. Include contacts who are in the 'Technology' industry, have attended any webinar hosted by us, and have downloaded the 'AI Trends 2024' whitepaper. The activity should have occurred in the last 6 months. Name the list 'Tech Engaged Webinar & Whitepaper - Last 6 Months'.

tasks.description: As a researcher, segment contact lists in HubSpot to identify specific groups for studies, outreach, or analysis based on various criteria like engagement, demographics, or custom properties. This involves navigating HubSpot's contact management features, defining segmentation rules, and saving the resulting lists.

example.scenario: A research team needs to identify HubSpot contacts who have downloaded their latest whitepaper on renewable energy and are registered for their upcoming webinar. This segmentation is crucial for targeted follow-up surveys and qualitative interviews.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, I need to create a segmented list in HubSpot. I want to include all contacts who have downloaded our 'Future of Renewable Energy' whitepaper AND are registered for the 'Green Tech Innovations' webinar. Can you detail the steps to set up this specific segment in HubSpot?

tasks.description: As a researcher using HubSpot, create and refine dynamic segments of your contact database based on various criteria such as demographic information, behavioral data (e.g., email opens, website visits, content downloads), company properties, and engagement levels. This task involves navigating HubSpot's list segmentation tools to define complex filter conditions, combine multiple criteria with 'AND'/'OR' logic, and preview/save segments for targeted analysis, study participant recruitment, or data export.

example.scenario: A researcher is conducting a study on user engagement with their online educational content. They need to identify a specific group of contacts for a follow-up qualitative interview. This group should consist of individuals who have completed at least one online course, visited the 'Research Insights' section of their website more than five times in the last quarter, and have an active subscription to their research newsletter.
example.userPrompt: Segment HubSpot contacts to find all individuals who have 'completed at least one online course', 'visited the /research-insights page > 5 times in the last 90 days', AND 'are subscribed to the 'Research Newsletter' email list'. Prepare this segment for export as a CSV.

tasks.description: As a researcher, draft a comprehensive and engaging blog post using HubSpot's content creation tools. This involves researching a topic, outlining the post, writing the content, incorporating SEO best practices (keywords, internal/external links), and formatting it for publication within the HubSpot platform. The goal is to produce high-quality content that attracts and educates the target audience.

example.scenario: A B2B SaaS company needs a blog post for their content marketing strategy. The marketing team has identified 'Leveraging AI for Personalized Customer Experiences' as a key topic to attract new leads. The researcher is tasked with writing this post and preparing it for publication in HubSpot.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, please write a blog post of approximately 1000 words titled 'Leveraging AI for Personalized Customer Experiences' for our B2B SaaS audience. The post should explain the benefits of AI in personalization, provide actionable strategies, include relevant industry statistics, and be optimized for the primary keyword 'AI customer experience'. Structure the content with clear H2s, bullet points, and include a call-to-action (CTA) encouraging readers to download our latest whitepaper on 'AI in Customer Service Automation'. Prepare the content ready for direct input into the HubSpot blog editor.

tasks.description: As a researcher, draft a comprehensive and SEO-optimized blog post within HubSpot's content editor, focusing on a specific industry topic and ensuring it aligns with the company's content strategy for lead generation.

example.scenario: You are a content researcher at an enterprise B2B software company. Your marketing team has identified a gap in content regarding 'Optimizing Customer Onboarding with AI'. Your task is to draft an engaging and data-driven blog post that educates potential clients, attracts organic traffic, and positions your company as a thought leader. This specific post is the second in a three-part series on AI applications in customer success, meaning it should build upon the foundational concepts introduced in the first post while introducing new, actionable insights. You will use HubSpot's blog editor to create, optimize, and prepare the content.
example.userPrompt: Draft a detailed blog post titled 'Optimizing Customer Onboarding with AI: Strategies for Seamless Integration'. The post should include an introduction highlighting the importance of efficient onboarding, 3-4 main sections detailing AI strategies (e.g., personalized learning paths, predictive issue resolution, automated check-ins), a conclusion summarizing key benefits, and a relevant call-to-action. Ensure the content is research-backed, easy to understand, and optimized for SEO using keywords like 'AI customer onboarding', 'customer success AI', and 'onboarding automation'. Utilize HubSpot's content optimization tools to refine the draft. This is the second post in our AI in customer success series.

tasks.description: As a researcher, leverage Excel's pivot table functionality to summarize, analyze, and identify patterns within large datasets. This involves selecting appropriate data sources, defining rows, columns, values, and filters to extract meaningful insights from survey results, experimental data, or other research findings.

example.scenario: A researcher has collected survey responses from 500 participants, including demographic information (age, gender, location) and their ratings on several product features. They need to analyze how feature ratings vary across different demographic groups.
example.userPrompt: Given my raw survey data in Excel, I need to create a pivot table to analyze the average rating for each product feature, broken down by participant age group and gender. I also want to easily filter by location.

tasks.description: A researcher uses Excel to create pivot tables for in-depth data analysis, summarizing large datasets, identifying trends, and comparing different variables to derive meaningful insights for their studies or reports. This involves setting up rows, columns, values, and filters to answer specific research questions.

example.scenario: A researcher has gathered extensive survey data from an experiment, including participant demographics and their responses to several experimental conditions. They need to quickly synthesize this data to identify significant relationships and prepare findings for a presentation or paper.
example.userPrompt: You are a researcher with a large Excel dataset containing participant IDs, demographic information (age group, education level), and quantitative results from three different experimental conditions. Your goal is to analyze the average performance for each condition, broken down by age group and education level. Create a pivot table that shows the mean performance for each condition, segmented by age group in rows and education level in columns. Also, include a filter for specific experimental conditions.

tasks.description: A researcher needs to use Excel to create pivot tables from raw data to summarize information, identify trends, and generate actionable insights for their studies or reports. This involves selecting data ranges, defining rows, columns, values, and filters to present data effectively.

example.scenario: A research team has collected extensive survey data on patient outcomes from various clinics. The dataset includes patient demographics, treatment types, and recovery metrics. The lead researcher needs to quickly identify the average recovery time based on treatment type and patient age group, and also count the number of patients per clinic.
example.userPrompt: How can I use Excel to create a pivot table that shows the average recovery time by treatment type and age group, and also counts the number of patients from each clinic?

tasks.description: A researcher utilizes Excel to create complex pivot tables for in-depth data analysis, summarizing large datasets, identifying trends, and generating reports from experimental or survey data. This involves organizing raw data, defining rows, columns, and values, and applying various aggregation functions and filters to extract meaningful insights.

example.scenario: A research scientist has collected sensor data from an experiment over several weeks, resulting in a large Excel spreadsheet containing timestamps, sensor readings, and experimental conditions. They need to summarize this data to understand average readings under different conditions and identify any weekly trends.
example.userPrompt: I have extensive sensor data from my experiment in Excel, including columns for 'Date', 'ExperimentCondition', 'SensorReading_A', and 'SensorReading_B'. I need to create pivot tables to analyze the average 'SensorReading_A' and 'SensorReading_B' for each 'ExperimentCondition' per week. How do I set this up in Excel, ensuring I can easily filter by week and compare conditions?

tasks.description: A researcher needs to synthesize key discussion points, decisions, and action items from a recent meeting and compose a clear, concise follow-up message to the team using Slack, ensuring all relevant stakeholders are informed and next steps are clear.

example.scenario: A research team has just concluded a crucial sprint planning meeting. As the lead researcher, you need to quickly disseminate the outcomes, assigned tasks, and deadlines to everyone involved, including those who couldn't attend, using Slack to ensure everyone is on the same page.
example.userPrompt: Please help me draft a concise and actionable Slack message summarizing the key decisions, action items, owners, and deadlines from our sprint planning meeting, ensuring it's easy for team members to digest and refer back to.

tasks.description: As a researcher, synthesize key discussions, decisions, and action items from a meeting and draft a concise, actionable follow-up message to be shared with the team or stakeholders on Slack, ensuring clarity and assigning responsibilities.

example.scenario: A researcher has just concluded a crucial project brainstorming session with their team. tasks.description: Assist a researcher in an iterative process of generating sophisticated Python code for advanced feature engineering tasks within Jupyter Notebooks. This involves exploring complex data transformations, aggregations, interaction terms, and encoding strategies to create highly impactful and robust features for machine learning models, with an emphasis on code reusability, interpretability, and methods for systematic experimentation and documentation.

example.scenario: A researcher is developing a fraud detection model using a complex transactional and behavioral dataset. They require advanced feature engineering code to transform raw data into predictive features, including time-based aggregates, interaction terms, and polynomial features, while also considering feature selection and high-cardinality categorical variable handling within an iterative Jupyter Notebook environment.
example.userPrompt:
As a researcher, I'm developing a fraud detection model in Jupyter. I need to generate Python code for advanced feature engineering, including:
1. Creating time-based rolling window features (e.g., sum of transactions in last 1, 7, 30 days, average amount, count).
2. Generating interaction features between existing numerical and categorical columns, and between pairs of numerical features.
3. Implementing polynomial features for specific numerical columns to capture non-linear relationships.
4. Handling high-cardinality categorical variables using advanced techniques like target encoding, M-estimators, or frequency encoding.
5. Providing code for systematic feature selection approaches (e.g., using correlation, mutual information, or tree-based importance with cross-validation).
6. Structuring the code for reproducibility, easy experimentation with different feature sets, and clear documentation of the feature creation process.
I'm working with a large, imbalanced dataset and need efficient pandas/scikit-learn implementations suitable for a production-level research project.

They need to quickly grasp the significant changes introduced by recent pull requests to understand the project's current trajectory and identify potential areas for deeper analysis.
example.userPrompt: As a researcher, summarize the key changes, discussions, and the overall impact of the last 20 merged pull requests in the 'pytorch/pytorch' repository on GitHub. Focus on identifying new features, significant performance improvements or bug fixes, and any notable shifts in architectural design or community contribution patterns that could inform my research into its development lifecycle.

tasks.task: Summarize GitHub Pull Requests for Research
tasks.description: A researcher needs to quickly grasp the scope, changes, and impact of one or more GitHub Pull Requests without reading through all code and comments. This involves synthesizing the PR title, description, commits, and potentially key discussion points into a concise, high-level summary suitable for academic or project-level understanding, focusing on conceptual changes rather than line-by-line code details.

example.scenario: A researcher is studying the evolution of a particular open-source project and needs to understand the purpose and key changes introduced by several significant pull requests (PRs) without delving into the full code review process for each. They want a high-level overview to identify trends, major feature introductions, or architectural shifts for their academic work.
example.userPrompt: I'm researching the recent developments in the 'microsoft/vscode' repository. Please provide a concise summary of Pull Request #170000 ('Introduce multi-root workspace support with a new settings architecture') focusing on its main objective, the problem it solves, and its primary technical contributions and impact. Exclude minor bug fixes or UI tweaks.

tasks.task: Develop data cleaning scripts in Jupyter Notebook
tasks.description: As a Content Creator, you need to prepare a raw dataset for an upcoming article or interactive report. tasks.task: Write data cleaning scripts for content analysis
tasks.description: As a Content Creator, develop and implement Python scripts within Jupyter Notebook to clean raw data sources (e.g., social media dumps, website analytics, survey responses). tasks.task: Develop Data Cleaning Scripts in Jupyter
tasks.description: As a Content Creator, leverage Jupyter Notebook to write and execute Python scripts for cleaning a given dataset, ensuring data quality and readiness for analysis or content generation. This involves identifying missing values, handling outliers, standardizing formats, and transforming data.

example.scenario: A content creator has received raw audience engagement data for their latest video series. Before creating an infographic or summary report, they need to clean the data to ensure accuracy and consistency.
example.userPrompt:
Write a Jupyter Notebook script to clean a CSV file named 'audience_engagement.csv'. The script should:
1.  Load the data into a pandas DataFrame.
2.  Identify and handle missing values (e.g., fill with median/mode, or drop rows/columns if appropriate).
3.  Detect and address outliers in 'watch_time_minutes' and 'comments_count' columns.
4.  Standardize the 'region' column (e.g., 'USA', 'U.S.A.', 'United States' to 'United States').
5.  Convert 'engagement_date' to datetime objects.
6.  Save the cleaned data to a new CSV file named 'cleaned_engagement_data.csv'.

tasks.description: Develop Python scripts within Jupyter Notebook to preprocess and clean raw datasets, addressing issues like missing values, inconsistent formats, and outliers, to ensure data quality for analysis and content creation. Include polynomial features, interaction features, and features derived from datetime columns (e.g., day of week, hour of day). tasks.description: As a Content Creator, the task involves leveraging Jupyter Notebook to generate Python code snippets that demonstrate various feature engineering techniques. Interaction terms, 3. One-hot encoding for categorical variables, 4. Target encoding for high-cardinality categorical variables, and 5. A custom feature combining two existing numerical columns. tasks.task: Generate Feature Engineering Code in Jupyter
tasks.description: A Content Creator needs to generate Python code for feature engineering within a Jupyter Notebook. This task focuses on creating practical and illustrative code snippets using libraries like Pandas and Scikit-learn to transform raw data into features suitable for machine learning models. The generated code should be clear, well-commented, and ready to be integrated into tutorials, blog posts, or educational materials, demonstrating common techniques such as creating new features, handling time-series data, or aggregating information.

example.scenario: A Content Creator is developing an online course module on 'Applied Machine Learning for E-commerce Data'. They need practical code examples for students to understand how to prepare a transactional dataset for predicting customer churn. The goal is to engineer time-based and aggregate features from raw customer transaction data within a Jupyter Notebook.
example.userPrompt:
Generate Python code for a Jupyter Notebook that performs advanced feature engineering on a transactional dataset named `df_transactions`. The dataset includes columns like `customer_id`, `transaction_date`, `item_id`, `price`, and `quantity`. Assume `current_date` is '2023-10-31'.

I need to create the following features for each `customer_id`:
1.  **`days_since_last_purchase`**: Number of days between `current_date` and the customer's most recent `transaction_date`.
2.  **`frequency`**: Number of unique `transaction_date` entries per customer.
3.  **`monetary`**: Total spend (`price * quantity`) for each customer.
4.  **`avg_basket_value`**: Average spend per transaction for each customer.
5.  **`num_unique_items_bought`**: Count of unique `item_id`s purchased by each customer.
6.  **`purchase_lag_days`**: Average number of days between consecutive purchases for each customer.

The code should include necessary imports (Pandas, NumPy), generate a small sample `df_transactions` dataset for demonstration, and clearly comment each feature engineering step.

tasks.description: As a Content Creator, the task involves generating Python code snippets for various feature engineering techniques within a Jupyter Notebook. tasks.description: A Content Creator utilizing Jupyter Notebook to develop robust Python code for advanced feature engineering, focusing on creating meaningful new features from raw datasets. The code should include examples for creating polynomial features, interaction terms, aggregation-based features (e.g., mean, std, count per group), time-series features (e.g., day of week, month, lag features, rolling windows), and sophisticated categorical data transformations (e.g., target encoding, frequency encoding, one-hot encoding). tasks.description: As a Content Creator using Tableau, this task involves conceptualizing and sketching various dashboard layouts to effectively present data. They need to understand which content categories perform best, the average engagement for different types of posts, and identify top-performing articles to inform their next quarter's content strategy.

tasks.description: As a Content Creator, you need to automate repetitive tasks or enhance data manipulation capabilities within Excel by generating custom VBA macros. This could involve automating report generation, reformatting content data, or creating interactive dashboards for content performance tracking.

This involves merging cells, applying conditional formatting, and extracting key metrics. Manually, this takes over an hour each week.

The macro should import data from a specific sheet, clean up unnecessary columns, calculate the average engagement rate, highlight top 5 performing articles, and format the entire report with a predefined company style, including a summary table and a chart. The data source sheet is always named 'RawData' and the output should be on a new sheet named 'WeeklyReport'.

tasks.description: As a Content Creator, automate repetitive tasks and enhance productivity in Excel by generating custom VBA macros for data manipulation, formatting, and reporting.

example.userPrompt: As a Content Creator, I need to generate a VBA macro in Excel that automates the following steps: 1) import data from a specific CSV file into a new sheet, 2) remove duplicate rows based on column A, 3) apply a specific date format to column C, 4) apply conditional formatting to column F (e.g., green for values > 100, red for values < 50), and 5) create a pivot table summary on a separate sheet showing total views per content category.
